subsection_content:
Different risk factors are associated with each type of colitis. For example, the risk of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis (UC) is higher if you are between the ages of 15 - 30 (most common) or 60 - 80, are of Jewish or white descent, have a family history of people with UC, smoking, using birth control pills or NSAID pain relievers.
The risk of developing pseudomembranous colitis (PC) is higher for people taking long-term antibiotics, being hospitalized, receiving chemotherapy, taking immunosuppressive drugs, the elderly, and having had PC in the past. .
The risk of ischemic colitis (IC) is higher for people over 50 years old, have heart disease or are at risk of heart failure, have low blood pressure, have had abdominal surgery, etc.
Dr. Trung believes that people with risk factors for colitis should proactively go to the hospital for regular health check-ups for timely screening, detection and treatment.
